instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1278: What is A1278? A1278 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook or Macbook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2254, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2327, 820-2530, 820-2879, 820-2936, 820-3115..
definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: [solved]RAM slot issues on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Mid 2012 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message:
I have two <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> boards that have RAM slot issues. The bottom slots are bad so the MacBook works with one stick of RAM in the upper slot. When RAM is in the lower slot, it beeps and does not post.
What are my options? I'm not sure if this is repairable or if it's just a waste of time...

threads.title: [solved]RAM slot issues on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Mid 2012 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message: Only viable option is to max out the working slot with 8GB. You could quickly check if the dead slot has any stuck pins, but usually it is a waste of time.

threads.title: [solved]RAM slot issues on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Mid 2012 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message: Got it. I'll check for bent pins but most likely will install an 8GB DIMM.

threads.title: [solved]RAM slot issues on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Mid 2012 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>
threads.message: For me 110% of these have been a waste of time, don't use the dead slot. I usually charge customer for one 8 GB stick + profit, or remove the nonfunctioning stick and keep it moving.
